dk.nesos.camera
Class Camera

java.lang.Object
  dk.nesos.camera.Camera

public final class Camera
extends java.lang.Object

Simulates a simple camera in OpenGL.

Note: Upwards is defined to be the Vector [0, 1, 0]. OPTIMIZE: Look at surrounding view frustum with BoundingSphere (radius test for spheres) or AABB for quick initial test http://www.lighthouse3d.com/opengl/viewfrustum/index.php?remarks OPTIMIZE: Look at the paper by Assarsson and Moller: http://www.ce.chalmers.se/~uffe/vfc_bbox.pdf http://www.lighthouse3d.com/opengl/viewfrustum/index.php?remarks2

Author:
ndhb
See Also:
GLU.gluLookAt(float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float)

 void rotateX(float radians)
          Rotating the view around the X-axis can be achieved by multiplying the matrix:
[ 1 0 0 ] R_x(t) = [ 0 cos(t) -sin(t) ] [ 0 sin(t) cos(t) ]
with the direction vector.
 void rotateY(float radians)
          Rotating the view around the Y-axis can be achieved by multiplying the matrix:
[ cos(t) 0 sin(t) ] R_y(t) = [ 0 1 0 ] [ -sin(t) 0 cos(t) ]
with the direction vector.
 void rotateZ(float radians)
          Rotating the view around the Z-axis can be achieved by multiplying the matrix:
[ cos(t) -sin(t) 0 ] R_z(t) = [ sin(t) cos(t) 0 ] [ 0 0 1 ]
with the direction vector.

Constructor Detail

Camera

public Camera()
This constructor quickly sets UP a camera at [1, 20, 1] with direction [1, 0, 0].

That means the camera is located 20 units UP the Y-axis and looking down the X-axis.

Camera

public Camera(org.lwjgl.util.vector.Vector3f location,
              org.lwjgl.util.vector.Vector3f direction)
This constructor sets UP a camera and its direction at the supplied locations in 3D space.

beginOrthographicProjection

public static void beginOrthographicProjection()

beginOrthographicProjection

public static void beginOrthographicProjection(int width,
                                               int height)
Prepares an orthographic projection matrix. Saves the current projection matrix on the stack.

Remember to call endOrtographicProjection when done in orthographic mode

Parameters:
width - of the projection screen
height - of the projection screen

endOrthographicProjection

public static void endOrthographicProjection()
Restores the previous projection from the stack.

refresh

public void refresh()
Performs an update of the view.

After modifying the camera position or direction this method should be called to orient the OpenGL Modelview-matrix.

rotateAroundAxis

public void rotateAroundAxis(float radians,
                             org.lwjgl.util.vector.Vector3f axis)
Rotates the direction around an arbitrary axis (represented by a vector).

Parameters:
radians - the amount to rotate
axis - the vector representing the axis.

rotateX

public void rotateX(float radians)
Rotating the view around the X-axis can be achieved by multiplying the matrix:
              [ 1       0        0      ] 
   R_x(t) =   [ 0       cos(t)  -sin(t) ]
              [ 0       sin(t)  cos(t)  ]

with the direction vector.

Note. This method unfolds the matrix multiplication to avoid creating unnecessary objects (eg. Matrix3f).

Parameters:
radians - the amount to rotate

rotateY

public void rotateY(float radians)
Rotating the view around the Y-axis can be achieved by multiplying the matrix:
              [ cos(t)  0       sin(t)  ] 
   R_y(t) =   [ 0       1       0       ]
              [ -sin(t) 0       cos(t)  ]

with the direction vector.

Note. This method unfolds the matrix multiplication to avoid creating unnecessary objects (eg. Matrix3f).

Parameters:
radians - the amount to rotate

rotateZ

public void rotateZ(float radians)
Rotating the view around the Z-axis can be achieved by multiplying the matrix:
              [ cos(t)  -sin(t) 0       ] 
   R_z(t) =   [ sin(t)  cos(t)  0       ]
              [ 0       0       1       ]

with the direction vector.

Note. This method unfolds the matrix multiplication to avoid creating unnecessary objects (eg. Matrix3f).

Parameters:
radians - the amount to rotate
